title: The Narcissism of Modern Love (Aquinas vs. The Ego)
description:
Stop saying "I love you." You probably mean "I consume you."
 
0:00 ‚Äì The Dismantling (Loving a Person vs. Loving a Sandwich) 
0:52 ‚Äì The Application: Love as Self-Destruction 
2:11 ‚Äì The Pivot: Caritas & The Infinite 
5:05 ‚Äì Challenge: Dare to Love Unselfishly

Modern romance is a biological trick designed to turn other people into a mirror for your ego. We treat relationships like transactions: as long as they feed our dopamine and validate our feelings, we stay. The moment they require sacrifice, we discard them.

This isn't love. It's appetite.

In this video, we dismantle the modern definition of "Love" using the philosophy of St. Thomas Aquinas. We look at why real love (amor amicitiae) has nothing to do with romance and everything to do with self-destruction.

If you are tired of transactional relationships and ready for the terrifying reality of what it means to "will the good of the other," watch this.

Citations from the Summa Theologiae:
‚û°Ô∏è The Distinction (Desire vs. Friendship): ST I-II, q. 26, a. 4
‚û°Ô∏è The Definition of Love: ST I-II, q. 26, a. 4, co. ("Amare est velle alicui bonum.")
‚û°Ô∏è The Definition of Caritas: ST II-II, q. 23, a. 1

title: Nietzsche Was Right About Us
description:
We have infinite entertainment and zero purpose. The "Last Man" is here. #nietzsche #philosophy #modernity #dopamine #meaning #nihilism 

Nietzsche's concept of the 'last man' describes a person consumed by superficial pleasures, a state of being that leads to deep-seated nihilism. This video explores how modern society, with its constant entertainment and dopamine hits, fosters this kind of human psychology, leading to a prevalent sense of emptiness. It serves as a cultural criticism of our current state, arguing that this constant pursuit of shallow 'happiness' is a form of addiction rather than genuine fulfillment, ultimately impacting mental health and leaving us feeling that 'god is dead'.

Watch the full dismantling here: https://youtu.be/OLYeUwiGZl8

title: Why ‚ÄúHappiness‚Äù is Ruining Your Life (Aquinas vs. Dopamine)
description:
Stop trying to be happy. It‚Äôs a trap.

0:00 ‚Äì Why You Are Empty: Nietzsche's "Last Man"
1:14 ‚Äì "God Does Not Want You Happy" (The Freud Argument)
2:26 ‚Äì The Trap

We live in the age of the "Last Man." We have infinite entertainment, 24/7 dopamine on tap, and more comfort than any king in history. Yet, we have never been more anxious, depressed, or empty. Why?

Because you are confusing Pleasure (biology) with Joy (intellect).

In this video, we dismantle the modern obsession with "Happiness." We steel-man the atheist argument from Sigmund Freud, diagnose your dopamine addiction, and use St. Thomas Aquinas to explain why chasing pleasure is actually a form of torture.

This isn‚Äôt a sermon. It‚Äôs a diagnosis.

Why be Good? | C.S. Lewis‚Äôs "3 Parts of Morality"
description:
It can‚Äôt be wrong if it doesn‚Äôt hurt anyone else, right?

Follow along for a LIVE lecture on C.S. Lewis's "The 3 Parts of Morality" from his book "Mere Christianity," originally radio talks given by Lewis during World War II between 1941 and 1944. The BBC had invited Lewis to speak to the nation during a time of crisis, and Lewis rose to the occasion to deliver a rational, cogent case for Christianity.

This short landmark piece is important for at least 3 reasons: 
‚Ä¢ (1) it offers a balanced, three-dimensional view of morality (external harmony, internal harmony, and final destination) not often seen or appreciated in modern accounts of moral philosophy/ethics, 
‚Ä¢ (2) it underscores the necessity of inner virtue (the 2nd part), which is tied essentially to interpersonal relations (the 1st part), and 
‚Ä¢ (3) it connects morality to ultimate purpose and religion (the 3rd part‚Äîthe general purpose of human life), which grounds why we do the other 2 parts at all.

It is my view that Lewis is borrowing this framework from earlier ancients and medieval philosophers, prominently among them St. Thomas Aquinas.

‚ö†Ô∏èNOTE: I'll answer questions from the chat periodically, so please ask good ones!‚ö†Ô∏è

title: Dr. Benjamin Rush, M.D., Father of Psychiatry
C.S. Lewis‚Äôs "Men Without Chests" & The Subjectivity of Beauty
description:
Is beauty really in the eye of the beholder?

Follow along for a LIVE lecture on C.S. Lewis's "Men Without Chests" from his book "The Abolition of Man," a collection of three chapters which were originally a series of lectures Lewis delivered at the University of Durham in February 1943. 

This short landmark piece is important for at least 3 reasons: 
‚Ä¢ (1) it is a concrete reminder to take care to assess what sort of education one carelessly imbibes, including the philosophical theories one uncritically accepts without knowledge or consent, 
‚Ä¢ (2) it is a response to the relatively very new yet all-too-insidious scourge of Value Relativism (and Moral Relativism) plaguing our education systems and our public psyche, and 
‚Ä¢ (3) it is a champion of moral and emotional education which is so sorely lacking in Lewis's days all the way up to ours.

‚ö†Ô∏èNOTE: I'll answer questions from the chat periodically, so please ask good ones!‚ö†Ô∏è

title: Why Study Philosophy as a Christian? | Drew Loewen (Drew the Catholic)
description:
Enjoy my discussion with Drew Loewen (@DrewTheCatholic)

Filmed on location with the @CatholicCreatorGuild at the @StPaulCenter in Steubenville, Ohio. 

Special thanks & shoutouts to @DrewTheCatholic, @CatholicKyle, and all the creators who attended and worked tirelessly to put together the conference this year.

00:00 - Why I Use Philosophy Every Day  
01:12 - The Class That Changed Everything  
02:24 - Escaping the Cultural Cave: Seeing Through the Shadows

07:12 - Why the Big Bang Points to God  
10:48 - Doubt Your Doubts: When Faith Becomes Reasonable  
13:12 - The Road from Reformed Theology to Catholicism  
16:00 - Everyone Has Faith in Something  
19:12 - Why Christian Truth Is Relational at Its Core  
22:48 - The Dangers of Hyper-Individualism in Modern Culture  
28:48 - The Power of Philosophy in Catholic Formation  
33:36 - How Aquinas Changed the Way I Think  
38:24 - Fighting the Brain Rot: Catholic Creators in the Digital Age

title: How to Talk to Atheists (Without Losing Your Soul) | Joe Heschmeyer (Shameless Popery)
description:
Enjoy my discussion with Joe Heschmeyer (@shamelesspopery) of Catholic Answers (@CA-Live and @CA-Live-Clips). 

Filmed on location with the @CatholicCreatorGuild at the @StPaulCenter in Steubenville, Ohio. 

Special thanks & shoutouts to Joe, @DrewTheCatholic, @CatholicKyle, and all the creators who attended and worked tirelessly to put together the conference this year.

title: Are Atheists Being TOO "Rational"? ‚Äì A Discussion
description:
Enjoy this discussion between @godlessengineer and me. 

00:00 - Intro
01:12 - Dr. McAllister‚Äôs Background in Philosophy
04:48 - Responding to Friar Casey‚Äôs ‚ÄúFive Reasons‚Äù
06:00 - Are Atheists Too Empirical & Rational?
08:24 - Is Free Will Compatible with Atheism?
10:48 - Are Theists Just Using ‚ÄúMagic‚Äù?
13:36 - Magic, Superpowers, & the Divine
16:48 - Can God Exist Outside Time & Space?
26:24 - Multiverse vs. Cosmological Arguments
32:24 - What Does it Mean for God to Be ‚ÄúEternal‚Äù?
54:00 - Are Atheists Too Rational for Beauty & Awe?

‚ö†Ô∏èNOTE‚ö†Ô∏è This is a discussion. I don't do debates. I do discussions. Debate is a mastered skill, a skill I do not have, nor am I interested in acquiring it. However, I am open to anyone if they'd like to have a calm, civil, and reasoned discussion in a collaborative, cooperative endeavour to get at what's true.

title: Is X Good Because God Says So? ü§îü§®
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: Socrates vs. Jesus¬†‚Äì Parallels
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: The Essence of God's Goodness
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: Plato's "Euthyphro" Dialogue: What is "Goodness"? (or Piety?)
description:
Here is just the Dialogue‚Äìthe "Euthyphro" by Plato‚Äìno strings attached and no side quests. You found the sauce. [For the famous Dilemma, see: https://youtu.be/02Lrmn9VjWY ]

Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

0:00 ‚Äì¬†Intro to Socrates
2:45 ‚Äì¬†The Sophists vs. Socrates
7:11 ‚Äì¬†Context for the Dialogue
10:52 ‚Äì¬†Definition 1 - "Look at me!"
14:22 ‚Äì¬†Definition 2 - "Piety is what the gods love"
14:38 ‚Äì¬†Definition 3 - "Piety is what ALL the gods love"
18:10 ‚Äì Prelude to Definition 4 - Genus vs. Species
20:36 ‚Äì¬†Definition 4 - "Piety is a kind of justice..."
24:00 ‚Äì¬†Definition 5 - "Piety is some sort of knowledge..."
26:49 ‚Äì¬†Euthyphro goes in circles

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: Is God the Standard of Morality?
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: Seeking the Essence: "What is 'Orangeness'?"
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: Secular Moral Realism: Brute Facts??
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: Proof of God? The 3rd Way: Argument from Possibility & Necessity
description:
‚Äã@TheDrDerek  LiveStream 6.God's Existence: Aquinas's Ways 1-3.

Weekly at THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)!

My recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

"Does God Exist?" Join in as we discuss Ways 1-3 for God's existence: 
- (1) the Cosmological Argument from Motion, 
- (2) the Cosmological Argument from Efficient Causes, and 
- (3) the Argument from Possibility & Necessity. 
We find these three arguments (and the 5 Ways in general) in Thomas Aquinas's Summa Theologi√¶ I.2.3.co (https://www3.nd.edu/~afreddos/summa-translation/Part%201/st1-ques02.pdf) and his much longer Summa Contra Gentiles (https://basilica.ca/documents/2016/10/St.%20Thomas%20Aquinas-The%20Summa%20Contra%20Gentiles.pdf). He is not the originator of the 5 Ways; that we owe to Aristotle!

This LiveStream 6 is a continuation of LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason and all the topics below
- Is belief in God merely based on Faith? 
- Or can I use my Reason to know that God exists? 
- Aquinas's view on the harmony between Faith & Reason
... 
Please watch that LiveStream in conjunction with this one (and future ones on the remaining 5 Ways)!

Chat is open. Bring your questions!

title: 1st Step: Admitting There‚Äôs a Problem
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: Can God Command Evil?
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: Does Evolution Give Us Morality?
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Just God's Opinion?
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: Can Morality Be Derived from Evolution?
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: Socrates' Challenge: Do the Gods Really Need Us?
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: Is Confusion Ever a GOOD Thing?
description:
What is Aporia? "Aporia" ["confusion," "befuddlement"] literally means "without a passage," or "without a way forward." It happens ALL THE TIME. But is it a GOOD thing?

[For the famous Dilemma, see: https://youtu.be/02Lrmn9VjWY ]
[For the sauce, see: https://youtu.be/bYH4TyorWG8 ]

Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

0:00 ‚Äì¬†What is Aporia?
2:46 ‚Äì¬†My Peer-Reviewed Paper: "Aporia as Pedagogical Technique"
3:36 ‚Äì¬†The Start of Philosophical Exploration
6:07 ‚Äì¬†4 Ways Aporia is used in Plato's Dialogues
6:51 ‚Äì In Socrates's interlocutors/conversation partners
8:08 ‚Äì¬†In Socrates himself!
11:38 ‚Äì In Socrates's accusers
11:45 ‚Äì¬†As an invitation to the reader

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: Socrates' Unexpected Encounter Before His Trial
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: Why are Plato's Dialogues Open-Ended?
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: Exploring the Euthyphro Dilemma: A Philosophical Journey
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: Pascal's Wager: It's NOT About Proof! (The Pragmatic Truth)
description:
@TheDrDerek   Taken from LiveStream 8.Why You Should Believe in God (Pascal's Wager): https://youtube.com/live/QpZbHQBNKBw

Usual time: THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)! Chat is open. Bring your questions!

(0) Discover the reasoning behind Pascal's Wager and why you should believe in God. This video explores the concept of taking a leap of faith and the philosophical arguments that support belief in a higher power.

(1) Here, in this current LiveStream 8, we examine Blaise Pascal's famous "Pascal's Wager": 
- "Yes, but you must wager. There is no choice, you are already committed. Which will you choose then? Let us see: since a choice must be made, let us see which offers you the least interest. You have two things to lose: the true and the good; and two things to stake; your reason and your will, your knowledge and your happiness; and your nature has two things to avoid: error and wretchedness. Since you must necessarily choose, your reason is no more affronted by choosing one rather than the other. That is one point‚Ä¶" 

(2) We'll also be examining in particular this controversial passage: 
- ¬´ Naturellement m√™me cela vous fera croire et vous ab√™tira. ¬ª
- "Naturally, even this will make you believe and will stupefy you."

title: Socrates vs. Sophists: The Battle of Ideas
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: STOP Defining Atheism Like THIS! (The Correct Definition)
description:
@TheDrDerek   Taken from LiveStream 8.Why You Should Believe in God (Pascal's Wager): https://youtube.com/live/QpZbHQBNKBw

Usual time: THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)! Chat is open. Bring your questions!


(0) Discover the reasoning behind Pascal's Wager and why you should believe in God. This video explores the concept of taking a leap of faith and the philosophical arguments that support belief in a higher power.

(1) Here, in this current LiveStream 8, we examine Blaise Pascal's famous "Pascal's Wager": 
- "Yes, but you must wager. There is no choice, you are already committed. Which will you choose then? Let us see: since a choice must be made, let us see which offers you the least interest. You have two things to lose: the true and the good; and two things to stake; your reason and your will, your knowledge and your happiness; and your nature has two things to avoid: error and wretchedness. Since you must necessarily choose, your reason is no more affronted by choosing one rather than the other. That is one point‚Ä¶" 

(2) We'll also be examining in particular this controversial passage: 
- ¬´ Naturellement m√™me cela vous fera croire et vous ab√™tira. ¬ª
- "Naturally, even this will make you believe and will stupefy you."

title: Proof of God? The 2nd Way: Argument from Causation
description:
‚Äã@TheDrDerek  LiveStream 6.God's Existence: Aquinas's Ways 1-3.

Weekly at THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)!

My recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

"Does God Exist?" Join in as we discuss Ways 1-3 for God's existence: 
- (1) the Cosmological Argument from Motion, 
- (2) the Cosmological Argument from Efficient Causes, and 
- (3) the Argument from Possibility & Necessity. 
We find these three arguments (and the 5 Ways in general) in Thomas Aquinas's Summa Theologi√¶ I.2.3.co (https://www3.nd.edu/~afreddos/summa-translation/Part%201/st1-ques02.pdf) and his much longer Summa Contra Gentiles (https://basilica.ca/documents/2016/10/St.%20Thomas%20Aquinas-The%20Summa%20Contra%20Gentiles.pdf). He is not the originator of the 5 Ways; that we owe to Aristotle!

title: Atheism: A Narrow View or a Worldview?
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: The God You Imagine: Is It the REAL God?
description:
‚Äã@TheDrDerek 
Or: "Is the God from the 5 Ways the Christian God?" 
Or: "What are Some Limitations of the 5 Ways?"

Taken from LiveStream 7.God's Existence: Aquinas's Ways 4-5.

Weekly at THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)!

"Does God Exist?" Join in as we discuss Ways 4-5 for God's existence: 
- (4) the Argument from Degrees of Being and 
- (5) the Cosmological Teleological Argument from Design. 
We find these two arguments (and the 5 Ways in general) in Thomas Aquinas's Summa Theologi√¶ I.2.3.co (https://www3.nd.edu/~afreddos/summa-translation/Part%201/st1-ques02.pdf) and his much longer Summa Contra Gentiles (https://basilica.ca/documents/2016/10/St.%20Thomas%20Aquinas-The%20Summa%20Contra%20Gentiles.pdf). He is not the originator of the 5 Ways; that we owe to Aristotle!

Tags: #Philosophy, #Metaphysics, #Epistemology, #Ethics, #PoliticalPhilosophy, #Morality, #Goodness, #HistoryofPhilosophy, #IntrotoPhilosophy, #Faith, #ReasonvsFaith, #ReligiousRelativism, #MoralRelativism, #Whatistruth, #philosophy, #Christianity, #Catholicism, #Catholic, #faith, #journey, #seek, #believe, #belief, #religion, #religiousbelief, #epistemology, #epistemic, #freedom, #TrustingGod, #Apologetics, #DefenseofChristianity, #DefenseofFaith, #ChristianApologetics, #Hinduism, #Buddhism, #Islam, #Judaism, #disagreement, #worldview, #science, #technology, #philosophy, #worldview, #true, #truth, #Ontology, #Axiology, #Morality, #Goodness, #Whatisphilosophygoodfor, #SciencevsPhilosophy, #Scientism, #Cosmos, #Cosmic, #CosmicReality, #CosmicRays, #CosmicUnderstanding, #Universe, #Universespeaks, #Whydoscientistsdisagree, #Scientificstudies, #FlatEarth, #MoonLanding, #Aristotle, #Aristotelian, #AristotlesFourCauses, #4Causes, #FourCauses, #Teleology, #FinalCause, #Purpose, #Reason, #Aristotle, #Purpose, #Reason, #SciencevsPhilosophy, #Scientism, #Whatisphilosophy, #Religiousfaith, #faithinGod, #Aquinas, #FaithorReason, #WhattoBelieve

Ways 1-3 here: https://youtube.com/live/LJoLjdusi54

This LiveStream 6 and 7 are a continuation of LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason and all the topics below
- Is belief in God merely based on Faith? 
- Or can I use my Reason to know that God exists? 
- Aquinas's view on the harmony between Faith & Reason
... 
Please watch that LiveStream in conjunction with this one!

My recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g


Chat is open. Bring your questions!

title: Pascal's Wager: 3 HUGE Problems! (The Objections You NEED to Know)
description:
@TheDrDerek   Taken from LiveStream 8.Why You Should Believe in God (Pascal's Wager): https://youtube.com/live/QpZbHQBNKBw

Usual time: THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)! Chat is open. Bring your questions!

(0) Discover the reasoning behind Pascal's Wager and why you should believe in God. This video explores the concept of taking a leap of faith and the philosophical arguments that support belief in a higher power.

(1) Here, in this current LiveStream 8, we examine Blaise Pascal's famous "Pascal's Wager": 
- "Yes, but you must wager. There is no choice, you are already committed. Which will you choose then? Let us see: since a choice must be made, let us see which offers you the least interest. You have two things to lose: the true and the good; and two things to stake; your reason and your will, your knowledge and your happiness; and your nature has two things to avoid: error and wretchedness. Since you must necessarily choose, your reason is no more affronted by choosing one rather than the other. That is one point‚Ä¶" 

(2) We'll also be examining in particular this controversial passage: 
- ¬´ Naturellement m√™me cela vous fera croire et vous ab√™tira. ¬ª
- "Naturally, even this will make you believe and will stupefy you."

title: Moral Realism: Truths Beyond Divine Will
description:
Taken from LiveStream 11.The Euthyphro Dilemma: Is Morality Real, Or Just God's Opinion? https://youtube.com/live/Fs5swh6uE2s

The Euthyphro Dilemma is a common challenge posed by atheists regarding the nature of morality and divine commands. The Euthyphro Dilemma directly touches upon God's nature and the source of moral values, the nature of morality, meta-ethics, and different ethical frameworks. Anyone who is interested in the areas of Philosophy, Ethics, Theology, and Apologetics will find this topic highly relevant. This isn't just about ancient Greece, of course; it is a problem that still resonates today in discussions about morality and religion.

title: Independent, Sovereign, Absolutely Necessary Being
description:
‚Äã @DerekLMcAllister   Taken from LiveStream 7.God's Existence: Aquinas's Ways 4-5: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=klp4_mqRr24

Weekly at THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)!

My recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

"Does God Exist?" Join in as we discuss Ways 4-5 for God's existence: 
- (4) the Argument from Degrees of Being and 
- (5) the Cosmological Teleological Argument from Design. 
We find these two arguments (and the 5 Ways in general) in Thomas Aquinas's Summa Theologi√¶ I.2.3.co (https://www3.nd.edu/~afreddos/summa-translation/Part%201/st1-ques02.pdf) and his much longer Summa Contra Gentiles (https://basilica.ca/documents/2016/10/St.%20Thomas%20Aquinas-The%20Summa%20Contra%20Gentiles.pdf). He is not the originator of the 5 Ways; that we owe to Aristotle!

Ways 1-3 here: https://youtube.com/live/LJoLjdusi54

This LiveStream 6 and 7 are a continuation of LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason and all the topics below
- Is belief in God merely based on Faith? 
- Or can I use my Reason to know that God exists? 
- Aquinas's view on the harmony between Faith & Reason
... 
Please watch that LiveStream in conjunction with this one!

Chat is open. Bring your questions!

title: Is There an Intelligent Designer Behind Natural Laws?
description:
‚Äã @DerekLMcAllister   Taken from LiveStream 7.God's Existence: Aquinas's Ways 4-5: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=klp4_mqRr24

Weekly at THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)!

My recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

"Does God Exist?" Join in as we discuss Ways 4-5 for God's existence: 
- (4) the Argument from Degrees of Being and 
- (5) the Cosmological Teleological Argument from Design. 
We find these two arguments (and the 5 Ways in general) in Thomas Aquinas's Summa Theologi√¶ I.2.3.co (https://www3.nd.edu/~afreddos/summa-translation/Part%201/st1-ques02.pdf) and his much longer Summa Contra Gentiles (https://basilica.ca/documents/2016/10/St.%20Thomas%20Aquinas-The%20Summa%20Contra%20Gentiles.pdf). He is not the originator of the 5 Ways; that we owe to Aristotle!

Ways 1-3 here: https://youtube.com/live/LJoLjdusi54

This LiveStream 6 and 7 are a continuation of LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason and all the topics below
- Is belief in God merely based on Faith? 
- Or can I use my Reason to know that God exists? 
- Aquinas's view on the harmony between Faith & Reason
... 
Please watch that LiveStream in conjunction with this one!

Chat is open. Bring your questions!

title: A Man of the World Among Ascetics: Pascal's Paradoxical Life
description:
@DerekLMcAllister  Taken from LiveStream 8.Why You Should Believe in God (Pascal's Wager): https://youtube.com/live/QpZbHQBNKBw

Usual time: THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)! Chat is open. Bring your questions!


(0) Discover the reasoning behind Pascal's Wager and why you should believe in God. This video explores the concept of taking a leap of faith and the philosophical arguments that support belief in a higher power.

(1) Here, in this current LiveStream 8, we examine Blaise Pascal's famous "Pascal's Wager": 
- "Yes, but you must wager. There is no choice, you are already committed. Which will you choose then? Let us see: since a choice must be made, let us see which offers you the least interest. You have two things to lose: the true and the good; and two things to stake; your reason and your will, your knowledge and your happiness; and your nature has two things to avoid: error and wretchedness. Since you must necessarily choose, your reason is no more affronted by choosing one rather than the other. That is one point‚Ä¶" 

(2) We'll also be examining in particular this controversial passage: 
- ¬´ Naturellement m√™me cela vous fera croire et vous ab√™tira. ¬ª
- "Naturally, even this will make you believe and will stupefy you."


(3) See also my last LiveStreams on Thomas Aquinas's 5 Ways (or arguments for the existence of God):
- LiveStream 6 (Ways 1-3) here: https://youtube.com/live/LJoLjdusi54
- LiveStream 7 (Ways 4-5) here: https://youtube.com/live/klp4_mqRr24
These two are a continuation of 
- LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason.


(4) See also my recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

title: The Eternal Role of the Creator: Sustenance Beyond Creation
description:
‚Äã @DerekLMcAllister   Taken from LiveStream 7.God's Existence: Aquinas's Ways 4-5: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=klp4_mqRr24

Weekly at THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)!

My recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

"Does God Exist?" Join in as we discuss Ways 4-5 for God's existence: 
- (4) the Argument from Degrees of Being and 
- (5) the Cosmological Teleological Argument from Design. 
We find these two arguments (and the 5 Ways in general) in Thomas Aquinas's Summa Theologi√¶ I.2.3.co (https://www3.nd.edu/~afreddos/summa-translation/Part%201/st1-ques02.pdf) and his much longer Summa Contra Gentiles (https://basilica.ca/documents/2016/10/St.%20Thomas%20Aquinas-The%20Summa%20Contra%20Gentiles.pdf). He is not the originator of the 5 Ways; that we owe to Aristotle!

Ways 1-3 here: https://youtube.com/live/LJoLjdusi54

This LiveStream 6 and 7 are a continuation of LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason and all the topics below
- Is belief in God merely based on Faith? 
- Or can I use my Reason to know that God exists? 
- Aquinas's view on the harmony between Faith & Reason
... 
Please watch that LiveStream in conjunction with this one!

Chat is open. Bring your questions!

title: Proof of God? The 1st Way: Argument from Motion
description:
‚Äã@TheDrDerek  LiveStream 6.God's Existence: Aquinas's Ways 1-3.

Weekly at THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)!

My recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

"Does God Exist?" Join in as we discuss Ways 1-3 for God's existence: 
- (1) the Cosmological Argument from Motion, 
- (2) the Cosmological Argument from Efficient Causes, and 
- (3) the Argument from Possibility & Necessity. 
We find these three arguments (and the 5 Ways in general) in Thomas Aquinas's Summa Theologi√¶ I.2.3.co (https://www3.nd.edu/~afreddos/summa-translation/Part%201/st1-ques02.pdf) and his much longer Summa Contra Gentiles (https://basilica.ca/documents/2016/10/St.%20Thomas%20Aquinas-The%20Summa%20Contra%20Gentiles.pdf). He is not the originator of the 5 Ways; that we owe to Aristotle!

- "Yes, but you must wager. There is no choice, you are already committed. Which will you choose then? Let us see: since a choice must be made, let us see which offers you the least interest. Since you must necessarily choose, your reason is no more affronted by choosing one rather than the other. That is one point‚Ä¶"

title: Domino Effect: The First Cause #philosophy #religion #Christian #faith #God #education #science
description:
‚Äã@TheDrDerek  New time: THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)!

My recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

"Does God Exist?" Join in as we discuss Ways 1-3 for God's existence: 
- (1) the Cosmological Argument from Motion, 
- (2) the Cosmological Argument from Efficient Causes, and 
- (3) the Argument from Possibility & Necessity. 
We find these three arguments (and the 5 Ways in general) in Thomas Aquinas's Summa Theologi√¶ I.2.3.co (https://www3.nd.edu/~afreddos/summa-translation/Part%201/st1-ques02.pdf) and his much longer Summa Contra Gentiles (https://basilica.ca/documents/2016/10/St.%20Thomas%20Aquinas-The%20Summa%20Contra%20Gentiles.pdf). He is not the originator of the 5 Ways; that we owe to Aristotle!

This LiveStream 6 is a continuation of LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason and all the topics below
- Is belief in God merely based on Faith? 
- Or can I use my Reason to know that God exists? 
- Aquinas's view on the harmony between Faith & Reason
... 
Please watch that LiveStream in conjunction with this one (and future ones on the remaining 5 Ways)!

Chat is open. Bring your questions!

title: Either God Exists or Doesn't Exist
description:
@DerekLMcAllister  Taken from LiveStream 8.Why You Should Believe in God (Pascal's Wager): https://youtube.com/live/QpZbHQBNKBw

Usual time: THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)! Chat is open. Bring your questions!


(0) Discover the reasoning behind Pascal's Wager and why you should believe in God. This video explores the concept of taking a leap of faith and the philosophical arguments that support belief in a higher power.

(1) Here, in this current LiveStream 8, we examine Blaise Pascal's famous "Pascal's Wager": 
- "Yes, but you must wager. There is no choice, you are already committed. Which will you choose then? Let us see: since a choice must be made, let us see which offers you the least interest. You have two things to lose: the true and the good; and two things to stake; your reason and your will, your knowledge and your happiness; and your nature has two things to avoid: error and wretchedness. Since you must necessarily choose, your reason is no more affronted by choosing one rather than the other. That is one point‚Ä¶" 

(2) We'll also be examining in particular this controversial passage: 
- ¬´ Naturellement m√™me cela vous fera croire et vous ab√™tira. ¬ª
- "Naturally, even this will make you believe and will stupefy you."


(3) See also my last LiveStreams on Thomas Aquinas's 5 Ways (or arguments for the existence of God):
- LiveStream 6 (Ways 1-3) here: https://youtube.com/live/LJoLjdusi54
- LiveStream 7 (Ways 4-5) here: https://youtube.com/live/klp4_mqRr24
These two are a continuation of 
- LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason.


(4) See also my recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

title: Atheists: If God Doesn't Exist,... Why Do You Care?
description:
@TheDrDerek   Taken from LiveStream 8.Why You Should Believe in God (Pascal's Wager): https://youtube.com/live/QpZbHQBNKBw

Usual time: THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)! Chat is open. Bring your questions!


(0) Discover the reasoning behind Pascal's Wager and why you should believe in God. This video explores the concept of taking a leap of faith and the philosophical arguments that support belief in a higher power.

(1) Here, in this current LiveStream 8, we examine Blaise Pascal's famous "Pascal's Wager": 
- "Yes, but you must wager. There is no choice, you are already committed. Which will you choose then? Let us see: since a choice must be made, let us see which offers you the least interest. You have two things to lose: the true and the good; and two things to stake; your reason and your will, your knowledge and your happiness; and your nature has two things to avoid: error and wretchedness. Since you must necessarily choose, your reason is no more affronted by choosing one rather than the other. That is one point‚Ä¶" 

(2) We'll also be examining in particular this controversial passage: 
- ¬´ Naturellement m√™me cela vous fera croire et vous ab√™tira. ¬ª
- "Naturally, even this will make you believe and will stupefy you."

title: Knowing God Exists, Without Knowing Anything ABOUT God
description:
@DerekLMcAllister  Taken from LiveStream 8.Why You Should Believe in God (Pascal's Wager): https://youtube.com/live/QpZbHQBNKBw

Usual time: THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)! Chat is open. Bring your questions!


(0) Discover the reasoning behind Pascal's Wager and why you should believe in God. This video explores the concept of taking a leap of faith and the philosophical arguments that support belief in a higher power.

(1) Here, in this current LiveStream 8, we examine Blaise Pascal's famous "Pascal's Wager": 
- "Yes, but you must wager. There is no choice, you are already committed. Which will you choose then? Let us see: since a choice must be made, let us see which offers you the least interest. You have two things to lose: the true and the good; and two things to stake; your reason and your will, your knowledge and your happiness; and your nature has two things to avoid: error and wretchedness. Since you must necessarily choose, your reason is no more affronted by choosing one rather than the other. That is one point‚Ä¶" 

(2) We'll also be examining in particular this controversial passage: 
- ¬´ Naturellement m√™me cela vous fera croire et vous ab√™tira. ¬ª
- "Naturally, even this will make you believe and will stupefy you."


(3) See also my last LiveStreams on Thomas Aquinas's 5 Ways (or arguments for the existence of God):
- LiveStream 6 (Ways 1-3) here: https://youtube.com/live/LJoLjdusi54
- LiveStream 7 (Ways 4-5) here: https://youtube.com/live/klp4_mqRr24
These two are a continuation of 
- LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason.

title: The Atheist is Guilty of Special Pleading!
description:
‚Äã@TheDrDerek Taken from LiveStream 7.God's Existence: Aquinas's Ways 4-5.

Weekly at THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)!

"Does God Exist?" Join in as we discuss Ways 4-5 for God's existence: 
- (4) the Argument from Degrees of Being and 
- (5) the Cosmological Teleological Argument from Design. 
We find these two arguments (and the 5 Ways in general) in Thomas Aquinas's Summa Theologi√¶ I.2.3.co (https://www3.nd.edu/~afreddos/summa-translation/Part%201/st1-ques02.pdf) and his much longer Summa Contra Gentiles (https://basilica.ca/documents/2016/10/St.%20Thomas%20Aquinas-The%20Summa%20Contra%20Gentiles.pdf). He is not the originator of the 5 Ways; that we owe to Aristotle!

title: Debating the Existence of God: A Philosophical Dilemma
description:
@DerekLMcAllister  Taken from LiveStream 8.Why You Should Believe in God (Pascal's Wager): https://youtube.com/live/QpZbHQBNKBw

Usual time: THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)! Chat is open. Bring your questions!


(0) Discover the reasoning behind Pascal's Wager and why you should believe in God. This video explores the concept of taking a leap of faith and the philosophical arguments that support belief in a higher power.

(1) Here, in this current LiveStream 8, we examine Blaise Pascal's famous "Pascal's Wager": 
- "Yes, but you must wager. There is no choice, you are already committed. Which will you choose then? Let us see: since a choice must be made, let us see which offers you the least interest. You have two things to lose: the true and the good; and two things to stake; your reason and your will, your knowledge and your happiness; and your nature has two things to avoid: error and wretchedness. Since you must necessarily choose, your reason is no more affronted by choosing one rather than the other. That is one point‚Ä¶" 

(2) We'll also be examining in particular this controversial passage: 
- ¬´ Naturellement m√™me cela vous fera croire et vous ab√™tira. ¬ª
- "Naturally, even this will make you believe and will stupefy you."


(3) See also my last LiveStreams on Thomas Aquinas's 5 Ways (or arguments for the existence of God):
- LiveStream 6 (Ways 1-3) here: https://youtube.com/live/LJoLjdusi54
- LiveStream 7 (Ways 4-5) here: https://youtube.com/live/klp4_mqRr24
These two are a continuation of 
- LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason.


(4) See also my recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

"Does God Exist?" Join in as we discuss Ways 4-5 for God's existence: 
- (4) the Argument from Degrees of Being and 
- (5) the Cosmological Teleological Argument from Design. 
We find these two arguments (and the 5 Ways in general) in Thomas Aquinas's Summa Theologi√¶ I.2.3.co (https://www3.nd.edu/~afreddos/summa-translation/Part%201/st1-ques02.pdf) and his much longer Summa Contra Gentiles (https://basilica.ca/documents/2016/10/St.%20Thomas%20Aquinas-The%20Summa%20Contra%20Gentiles.pdf). title: Making Claims about the Unknowable
description:
@DerekLMcAllister  Taken from LiveStream 8.Why You Should Believe in God (Pascal's Wager): https://youtube.com/live/QpZbHQBNKBw

Usual time: THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)! Chat is open. Bring your questions!


(0) Discover the reasoning behind Pascal's Wager and why you should believe in God. This video explores the concept of taking a leap of faith and the philosophical arguments that support belief in a higher power.

(1) Here, in this current LiveStream 8, we examine Blaise Pascal's famous "Pascal's Wager": 
- "Yes, but you must wager. There is no choice, you are already committed. Which will you choose then? Let us see: since a choice must be made, let us see which offers you the least interest. You have two things to lose: the true and the good; and two things to stake; your reason and your will, your knowledge and your happiness; and your nature has two things to avoid: error and wretchedness. Since you must necessarily choose, your reason is no more affronted by choosing one rather than the other. That is one point‚Ä¶" 

(2) We'll also be examining in particular this controversial passage: 
- ¬´ Naturellement m√™me cela vous fera croire et vous ab√™tira. ¬ª
- "Naturally, even this will make you believe and will stupefy you."


(3) See also my last LiveStreams on Thomas Aquinas's 5 Ways (or arguments for the existence of God):
- LiveStream 6 (Ways 1-3) here: https://youtube.com/live/LJoLjdusi54
- LiveStream 7 (Ways 4-5) here: https://youtube.com/live/klp4_mqRr24
These two are a continuation of 
- LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason.


(4) See also my recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

title: To Be or Not to Be? Understanding Contingency
description:
‚Äã @DerekLMcAllister   Taken from LiveStream 7.God's Existence: Aquinas's Ways 4-5: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=klp4_mqRr24

Weekly at THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)!

My recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

"Does God Exist?" Join in as we discuss Ways 4-5 for God's existence: 
- (4) the Argument from Degrees of Being and 
- (5) the Cosmological Teleological Argument from Design. 
We find these two arguments (and the 5 Ways in general) in Thomas Aquinas's Summa Theologi√¶ I.2.3.co (https://www3.nd.edu/~afreddos/summa-translation/Part%201/st1-ques02.pdf) and his much longer Summa Contra Gentiles (https://basilica.ca/documents/2016/10/St.%20Thomas%20Aquinas-The%20Summa%20Contra%20Gentiles.pdf). He is not the originator of the 5 Ways; that we owe to Aristotle!

Ways 1-3 here: https://youtube.com/live/LJoLjdusi54

This LiveStream 6 and 7 are a continuation of LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason and all the topics below
- Is belief in God merely based on Faith? 
- Or can I use my Reason to know that God exists? 
- Aquinas's view on the harmony between Faith & Reason
... 
Please watch that LiveStream in conjunction with this one!

Chat is open. Bring your questions!

title: Defining Atheism: It's NOT Negative
description:
@DerekLMcAllister  Taken from LiveStream 8.Why You Should Believe in God (Pascal's Wager): https://youtube.com/live/QpZbHQBNKBw

Usual time: THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)! Chat is open. Bring your questions!


(0) Discover the reasoning behind Pascal's Wager and why you should believe in God. This video explores the concept of taking a leap of faith and the philosophical arguments that support belief in a higher power.

(1) Here, in this current LiveStream 8, we examine Blaise Pascal's famous "Pascal's Wager": 
- "Yes, but you must wager. There is no choice, you are already committed. Which will you choose then? Let us see: since a choice must be made, let us see which offers you the least interest. You have two things to lose: the true and the good; and two things to stake; your reason and your will, your knowledge and your happiness; and your nature has two things to avoid: error and wretchedness. Since you must necessarily choose, your reason is no more affronted by choosing one rather than the other. That is one point‚Ä¶" 

(2) We'll also be examining in particular this controversial passage: 
- ¬´ Naturellement m√™me cela vous fera croire et vous ab√™tira. ¬ª
- "Naturally, even this will make you believe and will stupefy you."


(3) See also my last LiveStreams on Thomas Aquinas's 5 Ways (or arguments for the existence of God):
- LiveStream 6 (Ways 1-3) here: https://youtube.com/live/LJoLjdusi54
- LiveStream 7 (Ways 4-5) here: https://youtube.com/live/klp4_mqRr24
These two are a continuation of 
- LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason.

We find these three arguments (and the 5 Ways in general) in Thomas Aquinas's Summa Theologi√¶ I.2.3.co (https://www3.nd.edu/~afreddos/summa-translation/Part%201/st1-ques02.pdf) and his much longer Summa Contra Gentiles (https://basilica.ca/documents/2016/10/St.%20Thomas%20Aquinas-The%20Summa%20Contra%20Gentiles.pdf). He is not the originator of the 5 Ways; that we owe to Aristotle!

This LiveStream 6 is a continuation of LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason and all the topics below
- Is belief in God merely based on Faith? 
- Or can I use my Reason to know that God exists? 
- Aquinas's view on the harmony between Faith & Reason
... 
Please watch that LiveStream in conjunction with this one (and future ones on the remaining 5 Ways)!

title: Evidence: A Liberal View
description:
@DerekLMcAllister  Taken from LiveStream 8.Why You Should Believe in God (Pascal's Wager): https://youtube.com/live/QpZbHQBNKBw

Usual time: THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)! Chat is open. Bring your questions!


(0) Discover the reasoning behind Pascal's Wager and why you should believe in God. This video explores the concept of taking a leap of faith and the philosophical arguments that support belief in a higher power.

(1) Here, in this current LiveStream 8, we examine Blaise Pascal's famous "Pascal's Wager": 
- "Yes, but you must wager. There is no choice, you are already committed. Which will you choose then? Let us see: since a choice must be made, let us see which offers you the least interest. You have two things to lose: the true and the good; and two things to stake; your reason and your will, your knowledge and your happiness; and your nature has two things to avoid: error and wretchedness. Since you must necessarily choose, your reason is no more affronted by choosing one rather than the other. That is one point‚Ä¶" 

(2) We'll also be examining in particular this controversial passage: 
- ¬´ Naturellement m√™me cela vous fera croire et vous ab√™tira. ¬ª
- "Naturally, even this will make you believe and will stupefy you."


(3) See also my last LiveStreams on Thomas Aquinas's 5 Ways (or arguments for the existence of God):
- LiveStream 6 (Ways 1-3) here: https://youtube.com/live/LJoLjdusi54
- LiveStream 7 (Ways 4-5) here: https://youtube.com/live/klp4_mqRr24
These two are a continuation of 
- LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason.


(4) See also my recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

title: Is Not Believing the Same as Denying God?
description:
@DerekLMcAllister  Taken from LiveStream 8.Why You Should Believe in God (Pascal's Wager): https://youtube.com/live/QpZbHQBNKBw

Usual time: THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)! Chat is open. Bring your questions!


(0) Discover the reasoning behind Pascal's Wager and why you should believe in God. This video explores the concept of taking a leap of faith and the philosophical arguments that support belief in a higher power.

(1) Here, in this current LiveStream 8, we examine Blaise Pascal's famous "Pascal's Wager": 
- "Yes, but you must wager. There is no choice, you are already committed. Which will you choose then? Let us see: since a choice must be made, let us see which offers you the least interest. You have two things to lose: the true and the good; and two things to stake; your reason and your will, your knowledge and your happiness; and your nature has two things to avoid: error and wretchedness. Since you must necessarily choose, your reason is no more affronted by choosing one rather than the other. That is one point‚Ä¶" 

(2) We'll also be examining in particular this controversial passage: 
- ¬´ Naturellement m√™me cela vous fera croire et vous ab√™tira. ¬ª
- "Naturally, even this will make you believe and will stupefy you."


(3) See also my last LiveStreams on Thomas Aquinas's 5 Ways (or arguments for the existence of God):
- LiveStream 6 (Ways 1-3) here: https://youtube.com/live/LJoLjdusi54
- LiveStream 7 (Ways 4-5) here: https://youtube.com/live/klp4_mqRr24
These two are a continuation of 
- LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason.


(4) See also my recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

description:
‚Äã@TheDrDerek  New time: THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)!

My recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

"Does God Exist?" Join in as we discuss Ways 1-3 for God's existence: 
- (1) the Cosmological Argument from Motion, 
- (2) the Cosmological Argument from Efficient Causes, and 
- (3) the Argument from Possibility & Necessity. 
We find these three arguments (and the 5 Ways in general) in Thomas Aquinas's Summa Theologi√¶ I.2.3.co (https://www3.nd.edu/~afreddos/summa-translation/Part%201/st1-ques02.pdf) and his much longer Summa Contra Gentiles (https://basilica.ca/documents/2016/10/St.%20Thomas%20Aquinas-The%20Summa%20Contra%20Gentiles.pdf). He is not the originator of the 5 Ways; that we owe to Aristotle!

This LiveStream 6 is a continuation of LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason and all the topics below
- Is belief in God merely based on Faith? 
- Or can I use my Reason to know that God exists? 
- Aquinas's view on the harmony between Faith & Reason
... 
Please watch that LiveStream in conjunction with this one (and future ones on the remaining 5 Ways)!

Chat is open. Bring your questions!

(0) Discover the reasoning behind Pascal's Wager and why you should believe in God. This video explores the concept of taking a leap of faith and the philosophical arguments that support belief in a higher power.

(1) Here, in this current LiveStream 8, we examine Blaise Pascal's famous "Pascal's Wager": 
- "Yes, but you must wager. There is no choice, you are already committed. Which will you choose then? Let us see: since a choice must be made, let us see which offers you the least interest. You have two things to lose: the true and the good; and two things to stake; your reason and your will, your knowledge and your happiness; and your nature has two things to avoid: error and wretchedness. Since you must necessarily choose, your reason is no more affronted by choosing one rather than the other. That is one point‚Ä¶" 

(2) We'll also be examining in particular this controversial passage: 
- ¬´ Naturellement m√™me cela vous fera croire et vous ab√™tira. ¬ª
- "Naturally, even this will make you believe and will stupefy you."


(3) See also my last LiveStreams on Thomas Aquinas's 5 Ways (or arguments for the existence of God):
- LiveStream 6 (Ways 1-3) here: https://youtube.com/live/LJoLjdusi54
- LiveStream 7 (Ways 4-5) here: https://youtube.com/live/klp4_mqRr24
These two are a continuation of 
- LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason.


(4) See also my recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

"Does God Exist?" Join in as we discuss Ways 1-3 for God's existence: 
- (1) the Cosmological Argument from Motion, 
- (2) the Cosmological Argument from Efficient Causes, and 
- (3) the Argument from Possibility & Necessity. 
We find these three arguments (and the 5 Ways in general) in Thomas Aquinas's Summa Theologi√¶ I.2.3.co (https://www3.nd.edu/~afreddos/summa-translation/Part%201/st1-ques02.pdf) and his much longer Summa Contra Gentiles (https://basilica.ca/documents/2016/10/St.%20Thomas%20Aquinas-The%20Summa%20Contra%20Gentiles.pdf). He is not the originator of the 5 Ways; that we owe to Aristotle!

This LiveStream 6 is a continuation of LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason and all the topics below
- Is belief in God merely based on Faith? 
- Or can I use my Reason to know that God exists? 
- Aquinas's view on the harmony between Faith & Reason
...

God's Existence: Aquinas's Ways 4-5
description:
‚Äã @DerekLMcAllister   LiveStream 7.God's Existence: Aquinas's Ways 4-5.

Weekly at THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)!

00:00 Introduction
01:01 Review of First 3 Ways & Background 
5:00 Inferred Attributes of God from First 3 Ways
13:30 The 3rd Way: Necessary Being & Independence
18:26 Empirical Knowledge & the Principle of Causality
23:08 Principle of Causality vs. Skepticism
28:32 The 4th Way: Argument from Degrees of Being
44:30 The 5th Way: Argument from Design (Teleological Argument)
48:30 Laws of Physics vs. Force of Gravity
52:30 Audience Questions
54:47 Ranking Arguments for God's Existence & Criticisms
56:53 Who I'd Debate
59:50 Limitations of the Arguments
1:11:06 Final Thoughts

My recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

"Does God Exist?" Join in as we discuss Ways 4-5 for God's existence: 
- (4) the Argument from Degrees of Being and 
- (5) the Cosmological Teleological Argument from Design. 
We find these two arguments (and the 5 Ways in general) in Thomas Aquinas's Summa Theologi√¶ I.2.3.co (https://www3.nd.edu/~afreddos/summa-translation/Part%201/st1-ques02.pdf) and his much longer Summa Contra Gentiles (https://basilica.ca/documents/2016/10/St.%20Thomas%20Aquinas-The%20Summa%20Contra%20Gentiles.pdf). He is not the originator of the 5 Ways; that we owe to Aristotle!

Ways 1-3 here: https://youtube.com/live/LJoLjdusi54

This LiveStream 6 and 7 are a continuation of LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason and all the topics below
- Is belief in God merely based on Faith? 
- Or can I use my Reason to know that God exists? 
- Aquinas's view on the harmony between Faith & Reason
... 
Please watch that LiveStream in conjunction with this one!

Chat is open. Bring your questions!

title: God's Existence: Aquinas's Ways 1-3
description:
‚Äã@TheDrDerek  LiveStream 6.God's Existence: Aquinas's Ways 1-3.

Weekly at THURSDAY 5:00pm (EDT)!

0:00 Introduction to Aquinas's First 3 Ways
0:48 Clarifying "Proving God's Existence"
2:10 Historical Context: Enlightenment & Postmodernism
6:41 Sources & Historical Endorsement of the Arguments
11:01 Navigating Aquinas's Summa Theologi√¶
14:16 The 1st Way: Argument from Motion - Premise 1
16:30 The 1st Way: Argument from Motion - Premise 2
17:41 The 1st Way: Argument from Motion - Premise 3
19:02 The 1st Way: Argument from Motion - Premise 4
21:40 The 1st Way: Argument from Motion - Conclusion
27:52 The 2nd Way: Argument from Causation
37:55 Proof of God?
43:19 Attributes of the First Cause
48:30 Addressing "God Needs a Cause" Criticism
52:50 The 3rd Way: Argument from Possibility & Necessity
1:10:25 Aristotle's Arguments for a Creator
1:14:20 Debunking Explanations for Religion

My recent interview with Elijah Moore:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLGoYVxqE4g

"Does God Exist?" Join in as we discuss Ways 1-3 for God's existence: 
- (1) the Cosmological Argument from Motion, 
- (2) the Cosmological Argument from Efficient Causes, and 
- (3) the Argument from Possibility & Necessity. 
We find these three arguments (and the 5 Ways in general) in Thomas Aquinas's Summa Theologi√¶ I.2.3.co (https://www3.nd.edu/~afreddos/summa-translation/Part%201/st1-ques02.pdf) and his much longer Summa Contra Gentiles (https://basilica.ca/documents/2016/10/St.%20Thomas%20Aquinas-The%20Summa%20Contra%20Gentiles.pdf). He is not the originator of the 5 Ways; that we owe to Aristotle!

This LiveStream 6 is a continuation of LiveStream 5 (https://youtube.com/live/a15uctOT5sY), in which we laid the groundwork for these arguments for God's existence when we discussed Faith vs. Reason and all the topics below
- Is belief in God merely based on Faith? 
- Or can I use my Reason to know that God exists? 
- Aquinas's view on the harmony between Faith & Reason
... 
Please watch that LiveStream in conjunction with this one (and future ones on the remaining 5 Ways)!

Chat is open. Bring your questions!

title: Is Mary the "Mother of God"? #Jesus #religion #Bible #church #education #history #podcast #YouTube
description:
‚Äã@DerekLMcAllister  Taken from Livestream 3, here: https://youtube.com/live/vx7GxEmCcqY?feature=share

1:01 Q: Who is your favorite Apostle?
3:58 Q: What did Christian worship look like in the early centuries of the Church?
9:49 Q: What do you think is driving the Evangelical adoption of Nestorianism (Mary not mother of God, just mother of Jesus) and other heresies? 
10:26 Nestorianism
11:09 Theotokos = "God-bearer"
14:52 John MacArthur on Mary being the "Mother of God"
17:51 Arianism
18:10 Unitarianism, Jehovah's Witnesses, & Mormonism (& Islam!)
18:29 hypostatic union
18:52 homoousios
19:17 Q: Did Constantine make Catholicism more pagan?
21:45 Edict of Milan (313 AD) & Edict of Thessalonica (380 AD)
23:43 Q: What actually is the Council of Nicaea?
27:04 Outcomes of Nicaea: Nicene Creed, 20 Canons, Easter's details
28:27 Myth 1: "Easter was established at the Council of Nicaea."
29:46 Myth 2: "They invented the divinity of Jesus at the Council of Nicaea."
32:27 Myth 3: "The Bible was compiled at the Council of Nicaea."


Potential topics: 
- Travels of the 12 Apostles
- Persecution & Martyrdom
- Writings of the New Testament
- Heresies
- Emperor Constantine & the Legalization of Christianity (313 AD)
- Council of Nicaea (325 AD)
- Desert Fathers & Mothers (4th century AD)

title: Earliest Evidence?
description:
‚Äã@TheDrDerek Taken from LiveStream Eps. 2 https://www.youtube.com/live/lB_BqQZjjPU

1:20 Q: What makes a Church Father a Church Father?
2:37  Q: What is the significance of the Church Fathers in the first few centuries AD? What did they do for Christianity writ large?
4:01 367AD - 39th Paschal letter of Bishop Athanasius contained the full & exact list of 27 NT books we have today.
5:18 The making of the New Testament canon of Scripture
9:31 Q: Why did the Church leave books out of the Bible?
11:14  Q: Origins of the Apostles Creed?
11:55 Early Church Creed in 1 Corinthians 15
15:50 First 300 Years
16:12 The Apostles (c. 30‚Äìmid-90s AD)
16:37 Apostolic Fathers/Patristic Era (c. mid-90s‚Äì150 AD)
16:45 Apologists Era (c. 150‚Äì300 AD)
17:10 Theologians Era (c. 300‚Äì600 AD)
18:00 Medieval Era (c. 500-1500 AD)
18:06 First 300 Years Examined (in detail)
20:18 Q: When Jesus told St. Peter, "Upon this rock I will build my Church," is that the exact moment that the Catholic Church formally came into existence?
20:37 Ecclesiology terminology: "Mystical Body of Christ", "People of God", "Ecclesia congregata", "Roman Catholic Church", etc.
24:02 Q: Since the teachings of the early Church Fathers aren‚Äôt found in the Bible, are they still Biblical? Are they still reliable?
26:08 "New Evidence that Demands a Verdict" by Josh McDowell
27:57 Q: What‚Äôs our earliest evidence of the New Testament?
28:00 P52 Fragment of John's Gospel (c. 125 AD)
29:23 Comparing to Homer's Iliad & Odyssey and Plato's Republic
30:23 Show & Tell Books: "Timeline Charts of the Western Church" https://www.amazon.com/Timeline-Charts-Western-Church-Peterson/dp/0310223539
31:14 Show & Tell Books: "Oxford Bible Atlas" https://www.amazon.com/Oxford-Bible-Atlas-Adrian-Curtis/dp/0199560463
31:46 Show & Tell Books: "A Dictionary of Early Christian Beliefs" https://www.amazon.com/Dictionary-Early-Christian-Beliefs-Reference/dp/1565633571
32:09 Doctrine of the Eucharist & Real Presence in St. Ignatius of Antioch, a disciple of the Apostle John!
34:30 Show & Tell Books: "The New Testament in Antiquity" https://www.amazon.com/New-Testament-Antiquity-2nd-Cultural/dp/0310531322
35:30 Show & Tell Books: "Christianity Through the Centuries" https://www.amazon.com/Christianity-Through-Centuries-Earle-Cairns/dp/0310208122
36:24 Show & Tell Books: "A Concise History of the Catholic Church" https://www.amazon.com/Concise-History-Catholic-Church-Revised/dp/0385516134
37:23 Show & Tell Books: "The Fathers of the Church: From Clement of Rome to Augustine of Hippo" https://www.amazon.com/Fathers-Church-Clement-Augustine-Hippo/dp/0802864597
37:43 Show & Tell Books: "Aeterni Patris: On the Restoration of Christian Philosophy" https://www.vatican.va/content/leo-xiii/en/encyclicals/documents/hf_l-xiii_enc_04081879_aeterni-patris.html
38:25 Show & Tell Books: "The Rise of Christianity: How the Obscure, Marginal Jesus Movement Became the Dominant Religious Force in the Western World in a Few Centuries" https://www.amazon.com/Rise-Christianity-Marginal-Religious-Centuries/dp/0060677015
39:55 Q: Did Constantine really help Christianity? 
41:27 Q: What is your favorite early Church council? 
41:57 Council of Jerusalem (49 AD)
42:53 Ecumenical, general councils
43:23 First 7 Councils
45:27 1st Council of Nicaea (325 AD)
45:33 Arianism & other heresies
47:39 Council of Chalcedon (451 AD)
49:00 Christology & the "Chalcedonian Box"
49:43 Apollinarianism heresy
50:04 Nestorianism heresy
52:52 Q: Why did they only start having Church councils after 300 AD? Why not earlier?

title: Together, We Can Do Great Things #bible #church #religion #christian #jesus #education #depression
description:
‚Äã@TheDrDerek Do me a favor and subscribe to the MTI's channel! https://www.youtube.com/@MotherTeresaInstitute


My Talk at the 2024 Colloquium in D.C.:
https://www.youtube.com/live/vQ2nuhTvfxU?si=Im0vJNm36ZOiaeUp&t=808
Dr. Derek McAllister - "'Darkness Radiant': Distinguishing Mother Teresa's Spiritual Darkness from Depression"

MTI Colloquium: 
Sept. 6, 2024 (Afternoon Session), Catholic University of America 

director@mtinstitute.org 
motherteresainstitute.org 

Bio:
Dr. Derek McAllister is on the Faculty of Philosophy at St. Mary‚Äôs Seminary & University in Baltimore, Maryland, where he teaches pre-theology seminarians.  He earned a Ph.D. in Philosophy from Baylor University, a M.A. in Philosophy from University of Arkansas, and M.A. in Philosophy of Religion and Ethics from Talbot School of Theology. His academic work centers around depression from a philosophical perspective, in particular, examining the modern-day concept of depression in comparison with many other symptomatically similar historical conditions‚Äîe.g., sloth/acedia, immoderate sorrow, melancholy, Kierkegaardian despair, the dark night of the soul, etc. His research draws upon themes in St. Thomas Aquinas, S√∏ren Kierkegaard, St. John of the Cross, and the Desert Fathers.


Media Coverage:
https://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/259219/mother-teresa-s-spiritual-darkness-was-not-depression-or-loss-of-faith-scholar-explains

Dr. Derek McAllister - "'Darkness Radiant': Distinguishing Mother Teresa's Spiritual Darkness from Depression"

MTI Colloquium: 
Sept. 6, 2024 (Afternoon Session), Catholic University of America 

director@mtinstitute.org 
motherteresainstitute.org 

Bio:
Dr. Derek McAllister is on the Faculty of Philosophy at St. Mary‚Äôs Seminary & University in Baltimore, Maryland, where he teaches pre-theology seminarians.  He earned a Ph.D. in Philosophy from Baylor University, a M.A. in Philosophy from University of Arkansas, and M.A. in Philosophy of Religion and Ethics from Talbot School of Theology. His academic work centers around depression from a philosophical perspective, in particular, examining the modern-day concept of depression in comparison with many other symptomatically similar historical conditions‚Äîe.g., sloth/acedia, immoderate sorrow, melancholy, Kierkegaardian despair, the dark night of the soul, etc. His research draws upon themes in St. Thomas Aquinas, S√∏ren Kierkegaard, St. John of the Cross, and the Desert Fathers.


Media Coverage:
https://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/259219/mother-teresa-s-spiritual-darkness-was-not-depression-or-loss-of-faith-scholar-explains

title: Depression OR Spiritual Desolation? #bible #church #religion #christian #jesus #catholic #depression
description:
‚Äã@TheDrDerek Do me a favor and subscribe to the MTI's channel! https://www.youtube.com/@MotherTeresaInstitute


My Talk at the 2024 Colloquium in D.C.:
https://www.youtube.com/live/vQ2nuhTvfxU?si=Im0vJNm36ZOiaeUp&t=808
Dr. Derek McAllister - "'Darkness Radiant': Distinguishing Mother Teresa's Spiritual Darkness from Depression"

MTI Colloquium: 
Sept. 6, 2024 (Afternoon Session), Catholic University of America 

director@mtinstitute.org 
motherteresainstitute.org 

Bio:
Dr. Derek McAllister is on the Faculty of Philosophy at St. Mary‚Äôs Seminary & University in Baltimore, Maryland, where he teaches pre-theology seminarians.  He earned a Ph.D. in Philosophy from Baylor University, a M.A. in Philosophy from University of Arkansas, and M.A. in Philosophy of Religion and Ethics from Talbot School of Theology. His academic work centers around depression from a philosophical perspective, in particular, examining the modern-day concept of depression in comparison with many other symptomatically similar historical conditions‚Äîe.g., sloth/acedia, immoderate sorrow, melancholy, Kierkegaardian despair, the dark night of the soul, etc. His research draws upon themes in St. Thomas Aquinas, S√∏ren Kierkegaard, St. John of the Cross, and the Desert Fathers.

title: "Buried with Christ in Baptism"? #Baptism #Sacraments #Theology #ChristianTheology #CatholicTheology
description:
See the full video here! https://youtu.be/bh8aN-juQmg

What is Baptism?
Why was Jesus himself baptized?
Can I be baptized more than once? 
Why do Catholics (& others!) baptize infants?
Does baptism save you?

Join me for a discussion of all these questions and more! This talk covers the material that I taught for the permanent diaconate programs (i.e., those training to become deacons in the Catholic Church) for the Archdiocese of Baltimore at St. Mary's Seminary & Univ. (1/18/25).

title: CAN YOU BEAT THIS PHILOSOPHERS QUIZ?!?
description:
Hildegard's "De Spiritu Sactu" - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HYzPR0nwcmY

0:31 1. Which philosopher went crazy, then died, upon witnessing a horse being whipped?
2:08 2. Which philosopher fell into a well because he was preoccupied with looking at the sky?
3:28 3. Which philosopher also invented a language, wrote a medical treatise, and composed music?
5:10 4. Which philosopher said ‚ÄúGod grant me chastity,...but not yet‚Äù?
7:07 5. Which philosopher invented calculus?
8:22 6. Which philosopher is known (affectionately) as the ‚Äúdumb ox‚Äù?
10:48 7. Which philosopher, after being found guilty in a court of law, asked for his sentence to be gourmet food?
13:49 8. Which philosopher told Hans Christian Andersen that his fairy tales sucked?
16:53 9. Which philosopher laid the groundwork for the Declaration of Independence?
18:08 10. Which philosopher was Alexander the Great‚Äôs personal tutor?
19:28 11. Which philosopher was the University of California named after?
19:55 12. Which philosopher was philosophically refuted by a Princess?
